name: Oak Tree
description: A large, deciduous tree known for its strong wood and impressive size.
plantingTechniques: Oak trees prefer well-drained soil and full sun exposure. They can be planted in spring or fall.
careRequirements: Oak trees require regular watering, especially during dry periods. They can be pruned to shape and remove dead branches.
environmentalBenefits: Oak trees provide shade, improve air quality, and offer habitat for wildlife.
regionalSuitability: Oak trees are suitable for planting in temperate climates with cool, moist summers and mild winters.

name: Red Mangrove
description: A salt-tolerant tree that thrives in coastal areas and plays a vital role in coastal ecosystems.
plantingTechniques: Red mangroves require a saltwater environment and can be planted in the intertidal zone.
careRequirements: Red mangroves are relatively low-maintenance and can tolerate harsh conditions. They are known for their unique root systems that help stabilize shorelines.
environmentalBenefits: Red mangroves provide habitat for fish and other marine life, protect shorelines from erosion, and sequester carbon.
regionalSuitability: Red mangroves are suitable for planting in tropical and subtropical coastal areas.

name: Fruit Tree
description: A deciduous tree that produces edible fruit, offering both food and environmental benefits.
plantingTechniques: Fruit trees prefer well-drained soil and full sun exposure. They can be planted in spring or fall.
careRequirements: Fruit trees require regular watering, fertilization, and pruning to ensure a healthy crop. They are susceptible to pests and diseases.
environmentalBenefits: Fruit trees provide shade, improve air quality, and offer a source of food for humans and wildlife.
regionalSuitability: Fruit trees are suitable for planting in temperate climates with sufficient sunlight and a growing season.

name: Amazonian Mahogany
description: A large, tropical tree that produces valuable hardwood and is crucial for rainforest ecosystems.
plantingTechniques: Amazonian mahogany requires a tropical climate with high humidity and rainfall. It can be planted in well-drained soil.
careRequirements: Amazonian mahogany needs regular watering and occasional fertilization. It is susceptible to pests and diseases.
environmentalBenefits: Amazonian mahogany is a keystone species in the Amazon rainforest, providing habitat for many animals and contributing to biodiversity.
regionalSuitability: Amazonian mahogany is suitable for planting in tropical regions with high rainfall and humidity.
